channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: United States and Allies Vow Long-Term Support for Ukraine
item.description: In the wake of widespread missile attacks by Russia, defense officials from more than 50 countries met to discuss Kyiv’s weapons requests. Germany delivered a new, ultramodern air-defense system and the Netherlands promised $14.5 million in missiles.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Protests in Iran Spread, Including to Oil Sector, Despite Violent Crackdown
item.description: Human rights groups say at least 185 people have been killed and thousands injured or arrested, but demonstrations that began after the death of Mahsa Amini have continued nearly a month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tehran, the capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Struggling in Russian Prison, Her Lawyer Says
item.description: Facing nine years in prison in Russia, the U.S. basketball star is struggling emotionally and worried that a swap deal to release her may not materialize, according to one of her attorneys.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kirill Kudryavtsev
item.media:description: Brittney Griner at a court outside Moscow in August. The United States has said that her detention and trial were politically motivated.

item.title: US Considers Easing Sanctions on Venezuela as Migration Surges
item.description: The Biden administration may allow the last American company producing oil in Venezuela to resume exports if the Maduro government takes steps to restore democracy.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan family crossing the Darién Gap between Colombia and Panama last month.

item.title: In Long-Contested Move, Paris Makes Sacré-Coeur a Historical Monument
item.description: The basilica, which sits atop the hill of Montmartre, is the second most visited site in the capital, after Notre-Dame.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sacré-Coeur Basilica in Paris. Paris’s City Council voted Tuesday to classify the Sacré-Coeur as a “historical monument.”

item.title: Some Ukrainians Brace for Possibility of Russian Nuclear Strike
item.description: Fears of more severe retaliation grew after the attack on Russia’s sole bridge to Crimea. But U.S. officials have said they think the chances of Moscow’s using nuclear weapons are low.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Running from the scene of a Russian bombing in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday. Moscow responded to the assault on the Kerch Strait Bridge with a series of missile attacks across Ukraine.

item.title: Liz Truss Stirs Uncertainty Over the U.K.’s Economic Plans
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss appeared to rule out cuts in public spending, as doubts about the fiscal soundness of the government’s program continued to roil the markets.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss leaving to address Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Young Journalists Fight to Keep Free Press Alive in Myanmar
item.description: The Southeast Asian nation has seen a relentless crackdown on free expression, with a small literary magazine emerging as one of the few remaining independent media outlets.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Myanmar is now one of the world’s most dangerous places for journalists after the army seized power in a coup last year.

item.title: Britain’s ‘Brexit Festival’ Is Under Investigation Over Cost
item.description: The festival, a series of exhibitions officially called “Unboxed: Creativity in the U.K.,” came to be known as the “Festival of Brexit.” It cost 120 million pounds.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Emily Macinnes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spectators watched as Paisley Abbey was illuminated for an art installation during an “Unboxed: Creativity in the U.K.” event, in Paisley, Scotland, earlier this year.

item.title: The Hunt to Arm Ukraine Leads to Difficult Choices for Some Nations
item.description: The U.S. and NATO are scouring the world for new sources of old weapons to send to Ukraine. But it risks as much peril for some nations as it does promise for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a Soviet-style assault rifle in Irpin in March. Ukrainian officials say their stockpiles of Soviet-style weapons, which many soldiers were trained to use, are running dangerously low.

item.title: One Nation Under Xi: How China’s Leader Is Remaking Its Identity
item.description: The leader’s nationalist effort to meld ethnic groups, an agenda increasingly central to his rule, is seen as a bulwark against internal divisions and threats from the West.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Yao Dawei/Xinhua, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting with members of ethnic groups in 2015.

item.title: Israel and Lebanon Reach Landmark Maritime Agreement
item.description: If ratified by both governments, the deal is expected to avert the immediate threat of conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, and could eventually help salve energy shortages.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Jalaa Marey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Israeli navy vessel patrolled the Mediterranean waters off Rosh Hanikra on the border between Israel and Lebanon on Friday.

item.title: Coronation of King Charles III Is Set for May 6
item.description: The king’s ceremony at Westminster Abbey, the first of its kind in seven decades, is expected to be considerably pared down from that of his mother.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The coronation will reflect the monarch’s role today and look toward the future,” Buckingham Palace said in a statement, “while being rooted in longstanding traditions and pageantry.”

item.title: Bombing Kyiv Into Submission? History Says It Won’t Work.
item.description: Even though it creates misery and loss, the methodical bombing of civilian centers has more often been shown to rally support for resistance.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after Russian missile strikes.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: China’s Covid Testing Problems
item.description: Plus President Biden’s security strategy and Myanmar cracks down on journalists.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing.

item.title: Biden’s National Security Strategy Focuses on China, Russia and Democracy at Home
item.description: The document, which every new administration is required to issue, was delayed last winter as it became clear that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was imminent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: In his strategy document, President Biden returned to a theme he has established since his second month in office, describing a coming struggle as one of autocracies versus democracies.

item.title: Poland Says Druzhba Pipeline Leak Was Probably an Accident
item.description: News of the episode raised energy security concerns, but a Polish energy official said there was no reason to suspect sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Kacper Pempel/Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters near the Druzhba pipeline in Poland where an oil leak was detected on Wednesday.

item.title: Abortion Bans Weigh on Republicans
item.description: Banning abortion is weighing on the party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Covid-Testing Strategy Comes Under Strain
item.description: Bills are piling up and infections are spreading, yet there are no signs that Beijing plans to rethink a cornerstone of its pandemic policy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

item.title: When a Country’s Cuisine Becomes a Cultural Export
item.description: South Korea has sought to protect and enshrine its national dishes — while also sharing its wonders with the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and David Chow
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: The E-Bike: The New Car Alternative
item.description: VanMoof, the Dutch e-bike company taking inspiration from Apple and Tesla, is one of the world’s hottest brands in a bike market remade by the pandemic. Will it help reshape urban transportation?
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Matt Williams

item.title: Books About London That Take You Through the City
item.description: Bernardine Evaristo, whose “Girl, Woman, Other” won the Booker Prize, invites readers into London, a city whose rich literary landscape is “for everyone, not just the privileged few.”
item.dc:creator: Bernardine Evaristo
item.category: The Five: The Untold Lives of the Women Killed by Jack the Ripper (Book)
item.media:credit: Raphaelle Macaron

item.title: Russia Arrests 8 People Over the Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Five are citizens of Russia, according to Russia’s domestic intelligence agency, the F.S.B., and the others are Ukrainian and Armenian.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from a fire on the Kerch Strait Bridge linking Crimea to Russia on Saturday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Calls for more weapons for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wave of attacks by Russia in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, left a large crater in a playground.

item.title: Pressure Grows for West to Give Ukraine Air-Defense Systems
item.description: After Russia bombarded civilian targets, G7 leaders pledged “undeterred and steadfast” financial and military support for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wave of attacks by Russia in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, left a large crater in a playground.

item.title: Biden: Putin ‘Totally Miscalculated’ on Reaction to Ukraine Invasion
item.description: In an interview with CNN, Mr. Biden said he had “no intention” of talking to the Russian leader at a meeting next month, but would consider discussions about freeing Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine Seeks an ‘Air Shield’
item.description: Plus Xi Jinping’s push for an indivisible Chinese identity and a warning for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident stood on her balcony opposite a heavily damaged building, struck by a Russian missile a day earlier in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Administration Considers Humanitarian Parole Program for Venezuelans
item.description: The program, an effort to deal with a surge in migrants, would be similar to one offered to Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: More than 150,000 Venezuelans have been apprehended at the southwestern U.S. border between October 2021 and the end of August.

item.title: For Venezuelan Migrants in South Florida, ‘Vision of a Certain Life’ Meets Reality
item.description: Doral, Fla., nicknamed “Doralzuela,” has become a destination for the many people fleeing a troubled country. There, they find support, and, ideally, a new home.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kujawinski and Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times

item.title: Lufthansa Says Passengers Can’t Use Apple AirTags to Track Checked Bags
item.description: It appears to be the sole airline saying that international standards don’t allow passengers to use the Bluetooth devices in the cargo hold. Apple said that regulators allow their use for all baggage.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An Apple AirTag, designed to track and find personal belongings. It uses a standard watch battery and Bluetooth Low Energy radio technology to share its location.

item.title: Ukraine Under Attack: Images From the Russian Invasion
item.description: Photographers in and around Ukraine have captured the horrors of war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crews worked to extinguish fires and search for missing people after a Russian missile strike on a residential building in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Oct. 10.

item.title: NATO’s leader says Putin ‘is failing’ in the war and urges more weapons for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Stephanie Lecocq/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg holding a news conference in Brussels, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Vows ‘Consequences’ for Saudi Arabia After Oil Production Cut
item.description: Angered by the kingdom’s decision to team up with Russia, President Biden signaled openness to retaliatory measures, including a halt to arms sales and allowing price-fixing lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s willingness to consider retaliatory measures represents a significant shift for a president who had sought to improve relations with Saudi Arabia in recent months.

item.title: Hong Kong Declines to Seize Superyacht Linked to Russian Oligarch
item.description: The yacht, named Nord, is believed to belong to Alexei Mordashov, an ally of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Tyrone Siu/Reuters
item.media:description: The superyacht Nord, which is believed to belong to billionaire Alexei Mordashov, in the waters off Hong Kong, on Friday.

item.title: What Russia’s Missile Strikes May Indicate About Its Weapons Stockpile
item.description: Russia’s assault on Ukraine on Monday raised questions about the capacity of Moscow’s forces to carry out President Vladimir V. Putin’s military calculations.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian rocket serves as a reminder of the relentless bombardment of Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Miners Rescued After Being Trapped by Russian Airstrikes
item.description: Dozens of miners in Kryvyi Rih spent hours trapped underground after strikes that left many areas without power, a local official said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Enjoli Liston
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photo from May showing workers at the Metinvest Group Central Mining and Processing Plant in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, taking shelter in an underground bunker.

item.title: Russia’s Revenge
item.description: After weeks of setbacks on the battlefield, Russia struck civilian targets in Ukraine. But Vladimir Putin’s missiles may not accomplish much.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Pivot From N.F.L. Safety to Neurosurgeon
item.description: When Myron Rolle was cut from the Pittsburgh Steelers, he fell into a funk until his mother reminded him of his two childhood dreams: Play football, then become a neurosurgeon. It was time for Plan B.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Myron Rolle became a neurosurgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital after his football glory days ended.

item.title: Russian forces targeted civilians in previous conflicts.
item.description: Russia’s attacks in Ukraine this week echo those of Moscow’s earlier military campaigns.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Georgian man looking at his apartment building that Russian bombing destroyed in 2008 in Gori.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia unleashes mass strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after the Russian bombardment.

item.title: Putin Unleashes Barrage of Missiles on Ukrainian Civilian Areas
item.description: The Russian president tied the attack to a bombing of the bridge to Crimea, and vowed that more strikes would follow if Russian targets were hit again.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after the Russian bombardment.

item.title: British Official Stresses Threat From China Even Amid Russian Aggression
item.description: The head of Britain’s GCHQ spy agency warned that the West should not lose sight of the technological challenge from China as it deals with the immediate problem of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Jade Gao/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The director of Britain’s cyber and electronic intelligence agency said he was skeptical about how far China would go to support Russia’s aggression.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia’s Retaliatory Strikes on Ukraine
item.description: Plus North Korea’s underwater missile silos and trouble in the Metaverse.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injured civilians at the scene of a Russian bombing in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: With Attacks on Ukraine, Putin Gives Hard-Liners What They Wanted
item.description: A sharp shift toward deadly strikes signaled that domestic pressure over Russia’s flailing war effort had escalated to the point where Vladimir Putin felt a decisive show of force was necessary.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services workers on Monday at the site of an overnight missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian Strikes Batter Kyiv and Send Residents Dashing for Cover
item.description: The fighting in Ukraine had felt far from the capital in recent months, but the barrage of missiles brought many residents back to the fear and uncertainty of the early days of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Megan Specia and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injured civilians in Kyiv.

item.title: Airbus and Air France Go on Trial Over 2009 Rio-Paris Crash
item.description: Families of the 228 victims fought for years to bring the companies to court. Both face manslaughter charges.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Alexandre Severo, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Wreckage recovered after the crash of Air France Flight 447 was brought ashore in Recife, Brazil, in 2009.

item.title: Biden Condemns Russia’s Missile Strikes on Ukraine
item.description: The president reaffirmed U.S. support for Ukraine, but did not announce any new steps in response to Russia’s missile strikes.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden earlier this month. He did not announce any new measures from the U.S. or its allies in response to the strikes.

item.title: Striking Defense Lawyers in U.K. Agree to Return to Work
item.description: The government will increase legal aid fees by 15 percent for new and existing cases, ending a weekslong walkout.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Central Criminal Court of England and Wales (Old Bailey)
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Striking criminal barristers, the lawyers who argue cases in court, outside the Supreme Court in London in September.

item.title: Black Holes May Hide a Mind-Bending Secret About Our Universe
item.description: Take gravity, add quantum mechanics, stir. What do you get? Just maybe, a holographic cosmos.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Leonardo Santamaria

item.title: Lukashenko Says Russian Troops Will Return to Belarus in Large Numbers
item.description: Statements by President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an eccentric and highly erratic dictator, are rarely an accurate guide to current or future events.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Alexander Lukashenko at the Independence Palace in Minsk, Belarus, in May.

item.title: India and China Call for De-Escalation After Russian Strikes
item.description: Two key trading partners of Russia renewed calls for an end to the fighting, though they again did not directly criticize Moscow’s war.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vehicle that was destroyed in the attacks on Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Monday.

item.title: U.K.’s Young Hobbled by Inflation
item.description: Sharp price spikes are forcing the country’s young to move back in with family and worry about finances just as many were hoping to move past the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maisie Grattan, 21, left, and Evie Hargreaves, 22, at Ms. Hargreaves’ parents’ home, where they are both living temporarily as they face rising inflation.

item.title: Russians React to Attacks in Ukraine
item.description: Some younger Russians expressed sadness about the missile strikes in civilian areas, but were not ready to put the blame squarely on the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighter runs past residents evacuating from an apartment building in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, on Monday after a Russian attack.

item.title: In Kyiv, the strikes shattered what had become a relative sense of calm.
item.description: Russia’s attacks on Ukraine’s capital on Monday came after months in which the fighting had shifted to other parts of the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: In Southern Ukraine, Signs of Low Russian Morale Amid Retreat
item.description: The Ukrainians are making gains in the south, an area where Russian soldiers are dug in more securely and where their retreat has been less chaotic than in the north.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers riding in a captured Russian military vehicle in Velyka Oleksandrivka last week.

item.title: In Face of Drought, the Netherlands Reverses Course to Save Water
item.description: As climate change dries out Europe, the Netherlands, a country long shaped by its overabundance of water, is suddenly confronting drought.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Rob Engelaar/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A cargo barge on the severely depleted Rhine River at Lobith, the Netherlands, in August, when the river’s discharge hit a record low.
